I feel very conflicted on hermits patch history. On the one hand, I love that the designer has a clear goal of making sure the character is not overpowered, so many modded characters feel insanely over tuned and have tons of cards that are extremely strong or broken (That applies to the Watcher from the base game too), and it's really refreshing to play a modded character that actually feels a little underpowered and doesn't have many truly broken cards.

On the other hand, It feels pretty bad that anytime someone finds some cool way to combine his cards, or create a strong strategy to tackle some of the hardest encounters, it gets nerfed so quickly. It's okay for a few things to stand out as powerful, or for some rare synergy packages to come together every once in a while. Everyone wants to have those moments where things just feel good on a character and synergies start coming together and they feel rewarded for finding a good strategy. Just because something is doing well or is slightly overrepresented doesn't mean it needs a nerf, if anything, finding some ways to support the underperforming cards is a better approach to increase deck diversity. It just feels bad to see so many of his strong synergies get nerfed, and it really feels like hermit isn't particularly excelling in any areas right now
Yeah I think it honestly isn't as bad as I think it is, I just saw it go from the power level of a downfall class, and actually being pretty well balanced *among the downfall cast*

However I think that they want to balance it around the base 3 cast (watcher is an exception) and they are significantly weaker than downfall characters, and base game events etc. are less rewarding than downfall itself.
I think a lot of it is a mindset issue. I want hermit to be comparable in strength to downfall bosses, but I don't think it being similarly as strong as the base cast is a bad decision.
It's just tough to see a character fall so hard so fast
<Shadow cloak> rework is especially bizarre to me just due to how little exhaust hermit has

I think that the intention is to have hermit balanced closer to the first 3 characters from the base game (watcher really doesn't count, has some really egregious balance issues). I would say right now, hermit feels a little bit weaker than ironclad, silent, and defect. I don't think the designer has any intention for the hermit to ever be at the level of the downfall characters. I just wish that he had cleaner defensive scaling options for late game, I have tried many times to make maintenance + work, and it just isn't capable of matching the synergy of footwork, reflex, and backflip. I definitely agree that an extra way to exhaust curses at common/uncommon would make a ton of sense with the shadow cloak change, and would just generally make the curse generating cards feel easier to include in hermit decks as a whole. It feels like plated armor is designed to be hermit's traditional block scaling package, but it just doesn't hold up well against some of the very difficult fights in the game involving multi attacks (Heart, awakened one, book of stabbing, snake plant, gremlin leader, time eater, etc). Those fights are also awful for the rugged defense package. I pray for multiple flash powders every time I start a hermit run, feels like the best way to keep healthy over the course of a run and enable his rugged/plated armor cards to do their jobs more effectively.
I mean, hermit only has like 2 plated armor cards iirc
That's not really an archetype.

I like dissolve, fits in well with the ghostly theme of hermit, and is just a solid rare to include and buy some time to deal damage in fights. It's not a flashy or exciting card, but it does what it needs to do. From a flavor perspective, exhausting makes a lot of sense for dissolve, and it also has some precedence with cards like impervious, die die die, core surge, and seek. Lot's of "powerful one shot effect" cards have been at rare before and provide extremely efficient effects for their cost, then exhaust themselves so they can't be looped, and getting 2 turns of blur with enough block to realistically carry it over between turns fits within that design style. It does also work really well with the plated armor cards/relics.
it's not an archetype but <dive> can scale up extremely quickly when upgraded

I'm a sucker for scavenge, and I do often take dive. Dive+ is a legitimately great card to take if offered in act 2/3 in my opinion. 12 block for 1 energy, and 2 of that can keep going as plated armor. Snipe is also a very fun synergy piece for hermit in general if you can get enough dead on cards/ways to enable dead on, and can let you get up to 10+ plated armor fairly quickly with the right setup. It is also possible to just have a thread and needle on you, or brass tacks to help the plated armor stick around longer, or any of the defensive relics to support the setup (anchor, horn cleat, fossilized helix, etc). I wouldn't call it a full archetype, but it is a viable defensive package that works well until you reach some of the really nasty multi hit fights. Also, Thread and needle is fantastic in my opinion, it's 4/10ths of an anchor on turn 1, and continues to provide that same value every single turn of the fight (barring enemies getting through it). If the fight lasts even 3 turns, it will often mitigate more than anchor (which I would consider one of the best relics to have in the entire game, certainly in terms of consistent output). I don't really consider relic rarity that much, a relic is either helpful or it isn't. Rares do cost more at shops, but most of the time, you just get relics as a random result of opening a chest or beating an elite.
from what I have seen, Hermit's winrate is exactly in between IC and Silent

I just finished a run as hermit, and it was quite frustrating, I scraped by and won, but I felt behind the curve for most of the run. I was just wondering in a general sense what do you folks feel are hermit's biggest strengths? For example, watcher is excellent at bursting enemies down and crushing early game, silent has great mitigation and card selection tools, ironclad can exhaust down to infinites and is good at strength scaling, while defect has some of the best late game scaling in the game with orbs and powers. Hermit feels like they have a really tough time mitigating damage, and can get pretty beaten up in short hallway fights. I feel that their strongest attribute is damage multiplication through good access to vulnerable, bruise and strength scaling with determination and deadeye. Multihit cards like headshot, spray and pray, and spite all work really well in that shell to scale into lategame. I'm just wondering if there are any major synergies or niches that I'm missing with hermit that are particularly reliable beyond that? I will say that I am very scared of the curse related stuff in general, especially shadow cloak, it just feels so dangerous to lean into that pocket of synergy when every curse/curse generator you put in your deck makes it harder to draw the shadow cloak you need to actually pay you off. How are you folks building mitigation engines for lategame, because I am finding rugged and plated armor to be really poorly suited to many lategame enemies with multi-hit attacks.
You have to mix your defensive plans together
like take a few dive+, perhaps a gestalt, hole up+ is very efficient as well
adapt can work nicely

gestalt is great in the early game, against act 1 elites in particular it shines, but it has a much harder time against the heart, time eater, awakened one, nemesis, deca and donu, shield and spear etc. Dive+ is definitely one of my favorite mitigation tools. I find adapt to be a good effect, but very costly the turn you play it, really hurts without something like a mummified hand to help play more cards
I feel like shadow cloak is one of those few powers that actually should be innate on upgrade

It's simular to its a feature in that it's essential to get it in play asap with the core difference that Automaton can still function without playing if albeit in much weaker state while hermit just starts taking massive whenever he's not able to play it on first two turns
I don't think it's even possible to make a curse deck without shadow cloak considering how few other reliable defensive options there are for that kind of deck

Here's a 3 card combo that really helps mitigate curse hermits drawbacks <luck of the draw> to draw past curses <shadow cloak> to give them a benefit and finally <misfire> to get highly valuable curses for shadow cloak

Well the scaling not the misfire lol

Misfire and luck of the draw do seem like key pieces to generate more manageable curses, and draw into your shadow cloak/past your curses faster. I agree with gangur that an innate upgrade to shadow cloak would be extremely valuable, you already really want to find bottled tornado with it, because the more curses and curse generators you put in your deck, the harder it is to draw shadow cloak to actually benefit from them. A key difference to footwork is also the immediate impact on the turn you play shadow cloak, if you find it on turn 3 or 4 and then play it, you get far less immediate impact, and you fall even further behind. I'm starting to think that card draw is the answer here, just in order to get past curses, and to find your shadow cloak as fast as possible. Dead mans hand is a cool tool, but you will usually have rarer cards than shadow cloak it will be pulling instead.
That would make shadow cloak pair super well with <clasped locket>
